Cook visited them My companions amused at his idea
of dignity greeted
him with a hearty laugh, an he visited 'the native
traders first and then came to me with two
as a present I spoke to him about the
impolicy of the cond treatment we had received
at his hands and quoted 'the example ` 'of the Bangalas

To all this he agreed and then I gave his ˄ as a

2 iron spoons and 2 ydsyards `of crass painted calico
He looked rather saucily at these articles for he

24 ydsyards of calico & 2 bottles `of brandy from SnSenhor
Pascoal the Pombeiro otherOther presents were addedgiven
next day but we gave
nothing more and the Pombeiros informed me

they are accompanied by slaves and carriers who
are no great friends to their masters and if they

126
many slaves and their burde loads might be stolen
while passing through 'the forests. It is thus a sort
`of black-mail these insignificant chiefs levy and 'the
native traders in paying do so simply as a bribe to
keep them be honest. This chief was a man
`of no power but in our
former ignorance `of this
he plagued us a whole
day in passing - Finding 'the progress `of it SnSenhor Pascoal and 'the
other Pombeiros excessively slow I resolved to forgo his
company to Cabango after I had delivered to him some
letters to be sent back to Cassange, but on the
19th April the ˄ intermittentfever whwhich had begun on 'the 16th March
was changed into an excessively severe attack of
Rheumatic fever This was brought on by ˄ being obliged to sleeping
on an extensive plain covered with water The rain
poured down incessantly but we formed our beds by
dragging up 'the earth into oblong mounds somewhat like
graves in a country church yard and then placing
grass upon them The rain continuing to pour downdeluge us
we were unable to leave for two days, but as soon
as it became fair we continued our march
The heavy dew upon 'the high grass was so cold as tomade caused
shivering and I was forced to lay bye for eight days
tossing & groaning with in violent pain ` 'of the head This was 'the most severe
attack I had hadendured - It made me quite unfit to
move or ˄ even know what was passing outside my
little tent SnSenhor Pascoal who had been detained
by 'the ˄ same rain ˄ at a better spot at last came up and knowing that leeches
abounded in 'the rivulets procured a number and applied
some dozens to 'the nape ` 'of the neck and loins. He was
This partially relieved 'the pain heHe was then obliged
to move forward in order to purchase food for his
large party As some as After some time I
After
many days I
began to recover &
but ^ wished to move on but my men objected to 'the attempt
on account of my weakness When Sn. P.Senhor Pascoal reached
had been some time at ^ 'the villages in front as he had received instructions
from his employer CaptCaptain Neves to aid me as much as
127
possible ˄ and being himself a kindly disposed person he sent back two messengers to write me
to come on if practicable It happened that 'the head-
man ` 'of the village where I had lain upwards 22 days
had in bargaining ˄ & quarrelling in my camp with one `of my men for a piece `of
meat had been struck on 'the mouth by one of my men My principle
men paid as an 5 pieces `of cloth and a gun as an
atonement but 'the more they yielded 'the more
exorbitant he became and sent word to all
'the surrounding villages to aid him in avenging the
affront of a blow
on the beard As their courage usually rises with
success I resolved to yield no more and departed
In passing through a forest in 'the country beyond
we were startled by a body `of men rushing after us
They began by knocking down some ` 'of the last burden ˄ the burdens of the hindermost
`of my party and firing several shots were fired on
both sides, both ˄ each partiesy spreading out on eachboth sides
` 'of the path I fortunately had a six barreledbarrelled revolver
wh.which my friend CaptCaptain Henry Need of H. MHer Majesty's Brig
Linnet had considerately sent ˄ me to Golungo Alto after
my departure from LoandaLuanda Taking this in my
hand I staggered went rushed ba along back along 'the path
with two or three of my men and fortunately ˄ encountered found
'the chief ` 'of the village. The sight ` 'of the six barrels lookinggaping
into his stomach with my own
ghastly visage
looking daggers
at his face seemed to produce an instant
revolution in his martial feelings for he cryedcried
out "Oh I have only come to speak to you and
wish peace" only" to join the peace society Mashauana had
hold of him by 'the hand and found him shaking. We
examined his gun and found that it had been
discharged. Both parties crowded up to their
chiefs. One ` 'of the opposite party coming too near
one `of my men drove him back with an ˄ battle axe
The enemy protested their amicable intentions
and my men asserted the fact `of having ˄ the goodsbeen knocked
128
down ˄ as evidence `of the contrary withoutWithout waiting long I invitedrequested all to sit
down and Pi my man Pitsane placing his hand
upon 'the revolver ˄ somewhat allayed their fears I then said to the
chief "If you have come with peaceable intentions
we have no other Go away back to your village"
He replied "I am afraid lest you shoot me in the
back" I answeredrejoined "If I wanted to shootkill you I could shoot
you in 'the face as well" Mosantu called out to
me "That's only a Makalaka trick dontdon't give
him your back" but I rejoinedsaid tell him to observe that
I am not to observe that I am not
afraid of him and turning my back mounted my ox

There was not much danger in 'the fire that was
opened ˄ at first there being so many trees The enemy probably
expected that 'the sudden attack would make us
forsake our goods and allow them to plunder with ease
The villagers were no doubt pleased with being allowed
to retire unscathed and we were ˄ also glad to get away
without having shed a drop of blood or ˄ having compromisinged
ourselves infor any future visit. My men were
highly pleased with their own bravery and made
'the woods ring with telling each other what they would
have done had hostilities not been brought to a
sudden close I beleive I do not mention this
little affairskirmish as a very frightful affair. The negro
character in these parts and in Angola is essentially
cowardly except when influenced by success. A
partial triumph over any body `of men would
induce 'the whole country to rise in arms and this
is 'the chief danger to be feared These petty
chiefs have individually but little power and with
my men now armed with guns I could have easily
beatbeaten ˄ them off as singly ^ but being ` 'of the same family
they would readily unite in vast numbers if
incited by prospects `of successful plunder
129
They are by no means equal to 'the Cape Caffres in any
respect whatever ⎦In 'the evening we came to
Moenaki Kikanje and found him a sensible
man. He This is 'the last ` 'of the Chiboque chiefs in this direction and is
in alliance with Matiamvo whose territory commences
a short distance
beyond ^ here hisHis village is placed on 'the east bank ` 'of the Quango
whwhich Quilo whwhich is here 20 ydsyards wide and breast high
The country was generally covered with forest and
we slept every night at some village I was so
weak and and became so deaf fro from 'the effects ` 'of the fever that I was
glad to avail myself ` 'of the company `of SnSenhor Pascoal &
the other native traders Our rate `of travelling
was only 2 geographical miles per hour and the
average number `of hours 3½1/2 per day or 7 miles
One third ` 'of the month was spent in stoppages there
being only ten travelling days in each month The
stoppages were caused by sickness and 'the necessity of
remaining in different parts to purchase food, and also because
when one
carrier was
sick the
rest refused
to carry his
load

One ` 'of the Pombeiros had 8 good looking
women in a chain whom he was taking to 'the country
`of Matiamvo to sell for ivory They always
looked ashamed when I happened to come near them
and must have felt keenly their forlorn ˄ & degraded position
I beleivebelieve they were captives taken from the rebel
Cassange'sCassanges The way in wh.which slaves are spoken of
in Angola and eastern Africa must sound strangely
even to 'the owners when they first come from Europe
In Angola 'the common appellation is "P diabo" and
or "brutu" and it is quite common to hear gentlemen
call out "O diabo! bring fire" In eastern Africa
on 'the contrary they apply 'the term "bicho" (an animal)
and you hear the phrase "Call the "animal" to do
this or that." In fact slave owners come to
regard their slaves as not human and will
130
curse them as 'the race `of a dog The most of the
carriers `of my travelling companions were hired Basongo
and required constant vigilance to prevent theft ` 'of the goods
they carried. Salt wh.which is one ` 'of the chief articles con-
veyed into this country became considerably lighter
as we went along but 'the carriers shielded themselves
with by saying that it had been melted by 'the rain
Their burdens were taken from them every evening
and placed in security under 'the guardianship of
SnSenhor Pascoal's own slaves It was pitiable to observe
'the worrying life he led There was 'the greatest contrast
possible between 'the conduct `of his people and that of
my faithful Makololo

deep but narrow
stream by a
bridge It

larger & contains

It is the boundary
Londa on

25th March as above reaching 'the river Chikapa 'the 25th March we found it 50 ˄ or 60 ydsyards wide and flowing
to 'the east north east E N. EEast North East into 'the Casai. The
adjacent country is ` 'of the same level nature
as that part `of Londa formerly described
but having come nowfarther to 'the eastward than our
former course we found that all 'the rivers had
worn for themselves much deeper valliesvalleys than
those we at 'the parts we had formerly crossed them

The people `of these parts surrounded on all sides
by large gloomy forests have a much more
indistinct idea ` 'of the geography `of their country
than people those who live in hilly regions
itIt was only after long and patient enquiry that
I became fully persuaded that 'the Quilo runs
into 'the Chikapa. As we now crossed them ˄ both con-
siderably further down and were much to 'the
eastward there could be no doubt that these
rivers took 'the same course as 'the others into the
Casai and that I I had been led into a mistake
in saying that any `of them flowed to 'the westward
Indeed it was now only that I began to perceive
131
that all 'the western feeders ` 'of the Casai except 'the Quango
flow first from 'the western side towards 'the centre ` 'of the
country then gradually turn ˄ with the Casai itself round to 'the north and
after 'the confluence ` 'of the Casai with 'the Quango an immense
body `of water collected for all these branches
finds its way out ` 'of the country by means ` 'of the river Congo
or Zaire ˄ on the West
Coast The people living along 'the path
we are now following were quite accustomed to 'the
visits `of native traders and did not feel in any way
bound to make any presents of food except for 'the
purpose `of cheating, thus, a man gave me a present
`of a fowl and some meal and after somea short time
returned when I gave him a handsome present of
beads but these he declined and demanded a
cloth instead ˄ whwhich was far more than 'the value of his gift they did 'the same with
my men until we
had to refuse presents
altogether Others made high demands
because I slept in a "house `of cloth" and must be
rich They seemed to think that they had a perfect
right to payment for simply passing through
their village Beyond 'the Chikapa we crossed 'the
Camaue ? Camaue a small ˄ deep stream coming from 'the S S.Wsouth south west, flingflowing
Loajima ? in to 'the Chikapa On 'the 30 April we reached 'the Loajima
where we had to form a bridge to effect our passage

This was not so difficult an operation as some
might imagine for a tree had fallen was growing
in a horizontal position across part ` 'of the stream
and there being no want ` 'of the tough climbing plants
wh.which admit `of being knitted like ropes Mr Sn P.Senhor Pascoal
soon constructed a bridge The Loajima was
here about 25 ydsyards wide but very much deeper
than when we had I had crossed before on 'the shoulders
of MashuanaMashauana The last rain `of this season
had fallen on 'the 28th April and that had suddenly
been followed by a great decrease ` 'of the temperature

throughout this country exhibit as
great a variety of tastes as
appears on the surface of
society among ourselves - Many
of the men are dandies - their
shoulders are always wet
with the oil ^ dropping from their ˄ well lubricated hair

someSome thrum a musical instrument
the livelong day and when they

Many of these musicians
bare too poor to have iron
keys to their instruments, but
make them of bamboo &
persevere though no one
hears the music but them
-selves - Others try to appear

going out of their huts
except with a load of bows
and arrows or a gun

a canary in a cage - Ladies
may be seen carefully tending
little lapdogs where are intended
to be eaten - Their villages
are generally in forests & com-
-posed of numbers of groups
of irregularly planted brown
huts with banana and cotton trees
and tobacco standing around There areis also
at every hut a high stage erected for drying
manioc roots and meal and elevated cages
to hold domestic fowls Round baskets
are laid on their ˄ thatch of the hutssides for 'the hens to lay in and
on 'the arrival `of strangers both men women and
children ply their calling as hucksters

wWith a great deal `of noisy haggling; all their trans-
actions are conducted with a great civil banter
and good temper My men having 'the meat
` 'of the oxen whwhich we slaughtered from time to time for sale
were eagerly ˄ entreated applied to asked to exchange it for
meal, no matter how small 'the pieces offered
were it gave them pleasure to deal The forest
landscape around is green with a tint `of yellow 'the grass long
'the paths about a foot wide and generally wornworn
deeply in 'the middle The tall grass over hanging
when brushed against by 'the feet and legs disturbed
'the lizards and mice and occasionally a serpent
making them rustle causing a rustling amongst

animal is entrapped and eaten, gins are
seen on both sides ` 'of the path, every ten or fifteen
ydsyards for miles together The time ˄ & labour required to

cultivation would
afford food for any amount `of fowls or swine
but these the latter are seldom met with

? Passing on through forests abounding
in climbing plants many `of wh.which are so extremely
tough that a man is required to go in front
with a hatchet and when the burdens of the
carriers are caught they are obliged to cut 'the
climbers with their teeth for no amount `of tugging
will make them break The paths in all these
cases are so zigzag that a person may imagine
he has travelled a distance `of 30 miles which
when reckoned as 'the crow flies may not be 15

Moamba We reached 'the river Moamba on 'the 7th
May This is a stream `of 30 ydsyards wide ˄ & like all

The unwearied attentions of this good Englishman
from his first welcome to me when a weary

There were also some

Several of the native traders here
having visited the country of Luba
lying far to the North of this, and
there being ssome visitors also
from the town of Mai which
is situated far down the Casai
I picked up some information respecting
those distant parts In going to 'the town
`of Mai 'the traders crossed only 2 large rivers the
Loajima and ChihombaChihombo The Casai flows
a little to 'the EEast of 'the town ˄ of Mai and near which
and near to it ^ there is a long waterfall They describe 'the
Casai as there of very great size and that it
thence ^ then turns ro bends round to 'the W.West On asking
an old man who was about to return to his chief,
? Mai, to imagine himself standing at his home
and point to 'the confluence `of 'the Quango and Casai
he immediately turned and pointed to 'the westward
and said "When we travel 5 days ˄ (35 or 40 miles) in that direction
we come to it" He stated also that 'the Casai
137
received another river named 'the Lubilash. There
is but one opinion among 'the Balonda as to respecting
'the Casai and Quango They invariably describe the
Casai as receiving 'the Quango and beyond 'the confluence
assuming 'the name `of zZairé or Zerézeré. At 'the
and 'the Casai ˄ even previous to 'the junction is much larger
than 'the Quango from 'the numerous branches it
receives Besides those we have already
crossed we havethere is 'the Chihombo ˄ at Cabango and 42 miles beyond
this 'the C eastwards runs 'the Casai itself - fourteen
miles beyond that 'the Caunguesi, then 42 miles
further east flows 'the Lolua besides numbers `of little
streams all `of whwhich contribute to swell 'the Casai

About 34 msmiles EEast of 'the Lolua or 132 ms.miles E N. EEast North East of
Cabango stands 'the town `of Matiamvo 'the paramount
chief of all 'the Balonda The town `of Mai is
pointed out as to 'the N.N.W.North North West `of Cthis place Cabango or
and 32 days or 224 ms.miles distant or about
LatLatitude South 5° 45' The chief town of Luba
another independent chief is 8 days distant
farther ^ in 'the same direction or LatLatitude SSouth 4° 50' Judging
from 'the appearance ` 'of the people who had come for the
purposes `of trade from Mai the people in it are
in quite as uncivilized a condition as 'the Balonda
They are clad of a kind of cloth made of 'the inner
bark `of a tree Neither guns nor native traders
are admitted into 'the country `of ˄ the chief of Luba as 'the chief
entertains a dread of innovation If a native
trader goes thither he must cla dress like the
common people with in Angola with a loose
robe resembling a kilt The chief trades in
shells and beads only, his people kill 'the elephants
by means of spears poisoned arrows and
traps They all assert that elephantselephants' tusks
138
coming from that country are heavier and of
Par -Paragraph greater length than any other. / It is evident
from that all 'the information I could collect that
both here and
elsewhere ˄ 'the drainage `of Londa falls to 'the north and then
runs westward. The countryies `of Luba and of Mai
isare evidently lower than this and yet this is of no
great altitude probably not more than
3000 ft.feet above 'the level ` 'of the sea. Having here
received pretty certain information on a point
in whwhich I felt much interest namely whether
that 'the Casai was ˄ not navigable from 'the Coast owing to the
large waterfall near 'the town `of Mai and that
no great Kingdom existed in 'the region beyond
toward between ˄ this and 'the equator I would fain have visited
'the greatest Matiamvo. This seemed a very
desirable step as it is good
policy as well
as right
to acknowledge
the sovereign
of country forand I was assumed by both nBalonda
and native traders that a considerable branch of
'the ZambesiZambezi rises in 'the country east `of his town
and flows away to 'the South The people `of that
part named Kanel Kanyika and Kanyoka
living on its banks are represented to be both numerous
and friendly but Matiamvo will on no account
permit any white person to visit them as his
principleprincipal supplies `of ivory are drawn from them
Thinking that we might descend this branch ` 'of the
ZambesiZambezi to Masiko's and thence to 'the Barotse
I felt a strong inclination to make 'the attempt
The goods however we had brought with us to pay
our way had by the long detention from fever and
weakness in both myself and men dwindled to
a mere fragment and I being but slightly acquainted
with 'the Balonda dialect I felt that I could rather
make use of my powers of persuasion over presents
to effect my object From all I could hear
139
of Matiamvo there was no chance `of my being
allowed to proceed through his country to 'the southward
& If I had gone merely to visit him all the
goods would have been expended by 'the time I returned to
Quaban Cabango. We had not found mendicity
so pleasant on our way to 'the north as to induce us
to desire to return to it The country of Mat-
iamvo is said to be well peopled but they
have little or no trade They receive calico
salt gunpowder pottery coarse earthenware
and beads and given in return ivory, beeswax
and slaves They possess no cattle Matiamvo
alone having a single herd wh.which he keeps entirely for
'the sake ` 'of the fleshThe present chief is said tito
be mild in his govtgovernment and will depose an
under chief for unjust conduct heHe occasionalyoccasionally
sends 'the distance of a hundred miles or more
to behead an offending officer but though I
was informed by 'the Portuguese that he possesses
absolute power his name had less influence
over with ˄ his subjects with whom I came in contact
than that of Sekeletu over his peoples living
at a much greater distance from 'the capital

As we thought it best to strike away
to 'the S. E.South East from Cabango to our old friend
Katema I asked a guide ˄ from Muanzanza as soon as funeral
proceedings were over to this he agreed heHe
agreed to furnish one and also accepted a
smaller present from me than usual when
it was represented to him by Sn Pascoal
and Faria that I was not a trader. He
seemed to regard these presents as his proper dues
and as a cargo `of goods had come by SnSenhor Pascoal
he entered 'the house for 'the purpose `of receiving his

share and SnSenhor Faria gravely presented him

received it with expressions `of abundant gratitude
"Zambi Zambi" as these vessels are highly valued
because ˄ from their depth they can hold ˄ so much food or beer
The association of ideas was to my mind
so very ludicrous
that it was extremely
difficult was to my mind so ludicous made it difficult

equal to that of the donor and recipient

Several ` 'of the children ` 'of the late Matiamvo
came to beg from me but never to offer any
food Having spoken to one young man
named Liula (Heavens) about their stinginess
he soon brought bananas and manioc I liked
his 'the appearance and conversation
and believe
they would
not be difficult
to teach - but
their mode
of life would
be a drawback 'the The Balonda in this quarter
much more than that of ˄ handsome agreeable looking than any ` 'of the inhabitants
near 'the coast The women allow their teeth
to remain in their natu beautifully white
state and ˄ would be comely but for 'the custom of
inserting pieces of reed into 'the cartilage of 'the
nose They seem generally to be in good
spirits and spend their time in everlasting
talk funeral ceremonies & marriages This
flow `of animal spirits whwhich must be one reason
why they are such an indestructible race -

-- The habitual influence on their minds of
of the providence ^ 'the`of unseen spirits may have a tendency in 'the
same direction by preserving 'the mental
quietude of a kind of fatalism

We were forced to prepay our guide and his
father too & he went but one day although

and probably no disgrace will be attached to 'the
deed by Moun Muanzanza Among
